ClassSummary.summary: Represents a SQL statement to execute against a postgres database. This class cannot be inherited.
ClassSummary.remarks:
PostgresCommand features the following methods for executing commands at a postgres database:
Item Description
ExecuteReader
Executes commands that return rows.
ExecuteNonQuery
Executes commands such as SQL INSERT, DELETE, and UPDATE statements.
ExecuteScalar
Retrieves a single value (for example, an aggregate value) from a database.
You can reset the CommandText property and reuse the PostgresCommand object. However, you must close the PostgresDataReader before you can execute a new or previous command.
If a PostgresException is generated by the method executing a PostgresCommand, the NpgsqlConnection remains open. It is the responsibility of the programmer to close the connection.
Using the '@' symbol for paramters is now the preferred approach although the old pattern of using '?' is still supported. Please be aware though that using '@' can cause conflicts when user variables are also used. To help with this situation please see the documentation on the 'allow user variables' connection string option. The 'old syntax' connection string option has now been deprecated.

ExecuteNonQuery.summary: Executes a SQL statement against the connection and returns the number of rows affected.
ExecuteNonQuery.remarks: You can use ExecuteNonQuery to perform any type of database operation, however any resultsets returned will not be available. Any output parameters used in calling a stored procedure will be populated with data and can be retrieved after execution is complete. For UPDATE, INSERT, and DELETE statements, the return value is the number of rows affected by the command. For all other types of statements, the return value is -1.

While the is in use, the associated is busy serving the PostgresDataReader. While in this state, no other operations can be performed on the NpgsqlConnection other than closing it. This is the case until the method of the PostgresDataReader is called. If the PostgresDataReader is created with CommandBehavior set to CloseConnection, closing the PostgresDataReader closes the connection automatically.
remarks.note: When calling ExecuteReader with the SingleRow behavior, you should be aware that using a limit clause in your SQL will cause all rows (up to the limit given) to be retrieved by the client. The method will still return false after the first row but pulling all rows of data into the client will have a performance impact. If the limit clause is not necessary, it should be avoided.

Prepare.summary: Creates a prepared version of the command on an instance of postgres Server.

remarks.para: Prepared statements are only supported on postgres version 4.1 and higher. Calling prepare while connected to earlier versions of postgres will succeed but will execute the statement in the same way as unprepared.

ExecuteScalar.summary: Executes the query, and returns the first column of the first row in the result set returned by the query. Extra columns or rows are ignored.
ExecuteScalar.returns: The first column of the first row in the result set, or a null reference if the result set is empty

remarks.para: Use the ExecuteScalar method to retrieve a single value (for example, an aggregate value) from a database. This requires less code than using the method, and then performing the operations necessary to generate the single value using the data returned by a

CommandText.summary: Gets or sets the SQL statement to execute at the data source.
CommandText.value: The SQL statement or stored procedure to execute. The default is an empty string.

remarks.para: When the property is set to StoredProcedure, the CommandText property should be set to the name of the stored procedure. The user may be required to use escape character syntax if the stored procedure name contains any special characters. The command executes this stored procedure when you call one of the Execute methods. Starting with Connector/Net 5.0, having both a stored function and stored procedure with the same name in the same database is not supported. It is suggested that you provide unqiue names for your stored routines.

CommandTimeout.summary: Gets or sets the wait time before terminating the attempt to execute a command and generating an error.
CommandTimeout.value: The time (in seconds) to wait for the command to execute. The default is 30 seconds.
CommandTimeout.remarks: CommandTimeout is dependent on the ability of postgres to cancel an executing query. Because of this, CommandTimeout is only supported when connected to postgres version 5.0.0 or higher.

CommandType.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating how the property is to be interpreted.
CommandType.value: One of the values. The default is Text.

remarks.para: When you set the CommandType property to StoredProcedure, you should set the property to the name of the stored procedure. The command executes this stored procedure when you call one of the Execute methods.

LastInsertedId.summary: Provides the id of the last inserted row.
LastInsertedId.value: Id of the last inserted row. -1 if none exists.
LastInsertedId.remarks:
An important point to remember is that this property can be used in batch SQL scenarios but it's important to remember that it will only reflect the insert id from the last insert statement in the batch.
This property can also be used when the batch includes select statements and ExecuteReader is used. This property can be consulted during result set processing.

Parameters.value: The parameters of the SQL statement or stored procedure. The default is an empty collection.
Parameters.remarks: Connector/Net does not support unnamed parameters. Every parameter added to the collection must have an associated name.
